summary_md: Last round fixed the intended problem (fix N, q=ζ_N) and produced a uniform disproof of the periodicity claim. Key reductions: convert symmetrized q-binomial to the standard q-binomial so f_n(q)=∑ q^{i(i−n)} binom_q(n+i,2i), and use the n-OGF for bookkeeping. Writing n=xN+s and i=yN+r and applying q–Lucas at q=ζ_N factors each summand; summing over y gives diagonal binomial sums equal to Fibonacci numbers. Consequently each residue subsequence g_s(x)=a_N(xN+s) is a Q(ζ_N)-linear combination of F_{2x},F_{2x+1},F_{2x+2} and satisfies g_s(x+2)=3g_s(x+1)−g_s(x). In particular the subsequence n=xN obeys f_{xN}(ζ_N)=F_{2x+1}+C_NF_{2x}, hence grows and is not periodic. Explicit N=1 and N=2 formulas (Fibonacci) were recorded. Citations: Research Notes; Rigorous Proofs; Current Output.
one_line_summary: Fixed-N sequence a_N(n)=f_n(ζ_N) is nonperiodic — Fibonacci growth in residue subsequences.
highlights: Clarified scope: fix N and evaluate q=ζ_N (not q=ζ_n).
Residue decomposition via q–Lucas: write n=xN+s, i=yN+r to factor summands by residues.
Summing over y yields Fibonacci diagonal sums S_0,S_1, so g_s(x)=A_s F_{2x}+B_s F_{2x+1}+C_s F_{2x+2}.
Each residue subsequence satisfies g_s(x+2)=3 g_s(x+1)−g_s(x), a fixed linear recurrence (nonperiodic unless zero).
Uniform counterexample: for n=xN one has f_{xN}(ζ_N)=F_{2x+1}+C_N F_{2x}, so the subsequence is unbounded (hence no global period).
next_questions: Write a fully rigorous q–Lucas specialization proof at q=ζ_N and insert it into proofs.md.
Compute the constants A_s,B_s,C_s (in Q(ζ_N)) for small N to illustrate the decomposition numerically.
Investigate periodicity modulo primes (Pisano-type) for the residue recurrences and report any finite-field phenomena.
